stem: A 32-year-old client with schizophrenia was started on haloperidol 4 days ago. Based on the documentation in the Neuromuscular & Autonomic Stability Log, which complication is the client most likely experiencing?

rationale.correct: The client is most likely experiencing Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) (a1). NMS is a life-threatening reaction to dopamine-blocking antipsychotics like haloperidol. Key indicators differentiating NMS from Serotonin Syndrome include 'lead-pipe rigidity' (muscle stiffness), hyporeflexia (1+ reflexes), and a significantly elevated creatine kinase (CK) level (35,000 U/L) due to intense muscle contraction and breakdown. The high fever (104.2°F) and labile (fluctuating) blood pressure are also classic autonomic signs of NMS.
clinicalPearls: Priority interventions for NMS: 1. Stop the antipsychotic. 2. Initiate aggressive cooling measures. 3. Administer dantrolene or bromocriptine.
Elevated CK levels increase the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) due to rhabdomyolysis.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting Serotonin Syndrome (a2) due to the presence of a high fever.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the muscle tone. 'Lead-pipe rigidity' indicates NMS, while twitching/jerking (myoclonus) with hyperactive bowel sounds suggests Serotonin Syndrome.

mnemonic.title: N-M-S
mnemonic.expansion: N - Neural (Haloperidol). M - Muscle (Lead-pipe rigidity). S - Stone (Stiff/Stuck).

exhibits.title: Neuromuscular Exam
exhibits.content: Current: Muscles are extremely stiff and resistant to passive movement ('lead-pipe rigidity'). No rhythmic twitching noted. Reflexes are 1+ (sluggish/diminished).

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & Autonomic
exhibits.content:
Vitals: Temperature 104.2°F, Blood Pressure 184/108 (labile), Heart Rate 128.
Skin: Profuse diaphoresis.
Bowels: Bowel sounds are absent in all four quadrants.
